Right now we have 4 countries meeting the criteria, 5 really solid candidates (CO, FR, PE, MX, UK) and finally a new candidate is emerging from the shadows: IT. If Italy crosses the 550K cases threshold without reaching the peak, it is really likely that it will cross the 1M line too, no matter the measures. The argument: 1) First wave was about 250K cases, peak around 26 to 27 of March, 80-90K cases at the peak: total wave approximately 2.8-3.1 times the number of cumulative cases at the peak. 2) Second wave: if we assume that it will have 2.5 times the number of cumulative cases at the peak, to be conservative, we need 300K second wave integrated cases at the peak, which makes 550K total cases if we combine them with the first wave. Right now we are at one week of reaching this point of no return and there has not been any national lockdown announced, only curfews and relatively weak measures at restaurants. My guess is that Italy is another sure case. The only candidate country that I can imagine failing is Peru, which is right now 40 to 50 days away of the 1M mark. However if the average new daily cases were able to fall solidly below 1800 per day soon, it could saturate below 1M. My two other favorite 1M candidates out there: Germany and Ukraine. And citing the unclyclopedia and parodying Monty Python: "no one expects the Polish inquisition", pointing to another solid candidate.

Increasing the probabilities for the last bucket: right now the more conservative projections for the number of cases for December 31 are between 68-81M cases, while the first country has steadily hold between a 20-25% of those total cases, from which I expect the #1 country to have between 13-21M cases (more probably between 13.8-18.6M being conservative). Combine this with Zipf's law and it is more probable than not that there will be at least 12 countries with 1M cases. Remove Brazil and the US, and we are left with 10. Besides IN and RU, which are already confirmed, for the moment I can count 7 that are a pretty good bet: ES, AR, CO, PE, MX, FR, UK. Other probable candidates are IT, GE, UKR, SA. To give an example, if in Ukraine the new daily cases keep growing at the same rate since the summer, it will end up with 0.9M cases: factor in some autumn/winter acceleration of the trend, and we will easily break the 1M barrier. Citing @pstamp , "covid rules the world". P.S. Mental note: by November 1st, there should be 8 to 9 countries with more than 1M cases: US/IN/BR/RU + ES, AR, CO, FR and probably UK too. Just for note: Here is the scientific consensus about COVID-19 as of today. All these statements are supported by scientific evidence. 1) The infection fatality rate of COVID is several-fold higher than that of influenza. 2) There is no evidence for lasting protective immunity after getting the virus. 3) The virus is capable of re-infecting people. 4) Transmission of the virus can me mitigated by social distancing, hand hygiene and wearing masks. 5) The way many countries handled the first wave led to widespread demoralisation and diminishing trust. 6) Herd immunity is still unsupported by scientific evidence. 7) Countries like Japan, Vietnam and New Zealand, have shown that robust public health responses can control transmission allowing life to return to near-normal. Source: https://www.thelancet.com/lancet/article/s0140-6736(20)32153-x

For calculating additional cases in next 90 days, We can use following thumb rule:
-If the 7 day trend of cases are decreasing - multiply today's 7 day average of new cases by 40 times
-If the 7 day trend of cases is flat - multiply today's 7 day average of new cases by 80 times
-If the 7 day trend of cases are increasing - multiply today's 7 day average of new cases by 200 to 300 times @Anneinak , @cafebedouin what do you think?

Two things to consider: 1) the power-law distribution and 2) the soft exponential growth in cases. 1) The power-law distribution (or its cousin, the Zipf's law) is something that happens in a lot of phenomena: sizes of countries, relative probability of vocabulary in a language and probably pandemics too. It basically states that the relative importance of the n-th item of a list will be 1/n^a, with a some exponent. Here we will assume a = 1, which is the most common occurrence. Of course this is far from perfect, it breaks down after a certain n, and it can have notable exceptions (e.g. if we order counties by size, China and India break the law, but the rest of the countries do not; however if we order US cities by size, it works wonderfully well). Assuming that it works for the 50 to 100 most affected countries during the pandemic, I would expect the following: 1.a) The most affected country should have from 19 to 22% of total cases
1.b) The first ten countries in the list should account to 56 to 65% of total cases Does reality match expectations? Yes, it does (though not perfectly), as can be appreciated by the time evolution of the pandemic (explanation: day 1 is 1st of June, the numbers are the fraction of total cases within the first 10 countries and the most affected country): -9(day) First ten 0.703661 First one: 0.312331

But the moment the #1 country reaches 15M cases, it becomes overwhelmingly probable (> 86% if we assume the 50% error is 1-sigma in a Gaussian distribution) that the #10 country will reach 1M. 2) The soft exponential growth in cases tell us that right now we have 32M cases, growing at a rate of 1.4-1.5M cases every five days, and with a slight increase of about 2-4% in every five day cycle (the five day cycle is a bad choice by my part). 2.a) Linear growth from there to the end of the year: 61M cases, top country at 20% of total cases (12M cases), assuming a 50% deviation from Zipf's, at least 8 countries with 1M+ cases. Thus the answer to the question will be 6, but more probably 7 or 8. 2.b) Soft exponential growth of a about 4% every five days: 76M cases, top country at 25% of total cases (19M cases), assuming no significant deviation from Zipf's law, about 18 to 19 countries with more than one million cases. Thus the answer to the question will be 16 or 17. 2.c) Of course, the key uncertainty is not the total cases at the end of the year, but how much we will deviate from Zipf's law and if the deviation will continue to be in the direction of concentrating cases in the most affected countries. Unfortunately owing to Murphy's law there are much more ways in which we can end up with 12+ countries with more than 1M cases than the contrary. Thus I will concentrate the bulk of the probability in the last bucket.

I don't have advanced math skills, so I try to find simple math solutions. A pandemic has an exponential growth pattern, but only if there is not human intervention.  Because of human interventions, an exponential growth projection is not appropriate; it will be way too high. Linear growth can only come about by some combination of aggravating and mitigating human interventions, like lack/presence of social distancing/isolating; lack/presence of contact tracing; and adequate/inadequate numbers of tests. There's political variables:  the existence/lack of strong, clear leadership;  lack/presence of a commitment to transparency in reporting; lack/presence of funding for testing & tracing; and strength/weakness of government enforcement and infrastructure.  Sadly, many of the poorer countries are trying to pretend COVID isn't a problem and are tacitly hoping to achieve herd immunity; this will drive numbers of cases up. There's economic variables:  the ability/inability to afford adequate test kits and contact tracing; and the inability/ability of people to spend 2 weeks not working.  There's a certain subset of countries where there's funding for testing, but people cannot afford to isolate for 2 weeks; this subset of countries will drive up the number in this question. And there's human variables:  the willingness/unwillingness of people to believe experts/science, and  the willingness/unwillingness of people to follow best practice rules or laws.  I am reading more and more about people refusing to believe in the value of or comply with social distancing guidelines. Historically, pandemics hit in waves, with the 2nd wave worse than the first.  It seems to me that the 2nd wave is anticipated to hit this fall (as in the 1918-19 Flu pandemic).  So, it seems that even in places where COVID seems under control, there will probably be another surge in cases. Bottomline:  I think that the number of daily cases is going to continue to rise.  This rising tide will lift all boats, including ones that seem to be up on the shore.  I don't know what countries will be #7,8, 9 or 10, but I'm becoming convinced that they will exist by CYE.

I don't think many people are looking at the actual curves. South Africa won't hit a million unless they have a 2nd wave. Maybe they will, but it's not my bet... Peru, Colombia, Mexico, are all on the decline. Maybe they won't decline fast enough to avoid a million cases by end of year, but maybe they will.  There seems to be a partial herd immunity that every country hits at some point. I don't know whether there's a biological component or if it's all behavioral -- my best guess is it's a combination --- but once nations reach a certain extreme of cases they tend to reverse in number.  Total population of the country is probably the biggest factor. I rank Mexico as biggest risk to reach 1 million.  There are large countries such as Bangladesh and Pakistan which have likely already reached a million cases, but there's not enough testing to make it official.  These curves are sinusoidal and to that extent predictable. We shouldn't be surprised when say, Colombia hits a peak that looks like the peak of other countries and then declines quickly.

I downloaded data from ourworldindata.org [1], and calculated the date each country would reach one million cases with linear growth. (Total cases grow by the same amount each week. I used the change in total cases over the last week.) Based on this linear growth model, 7 countries reach one million cases by the end of the year: India (Jul 17), Russia (Aug 29), South Africa (Sep 19), Colombia (Oct 19), Mexico (Oct 26), Peru (Nov 14), Argentina (Dec 31). This is a linear growth model (grows by the same amount in each time step). Some countries will see faster exponential growth. It is difficult to say which countries, but given the history of this virus, there will be some.  There are 8 countries that would reach one million in 2021 with linear growth, and all have populations more than 10 million: Bangladesh, Chile, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Spain.  Estimate is the 7 countries from the linear growth model plus 1 surprise exponential growth country: 8 total.   Chart [2] shows 5 countries from the linear growth model (excluding India and Russia).
Chart [3] shows the 8 other countries that might hit exponential growth. links:

1 August update: Significantly revising my probability distribution toward bin 4 based on a re-evaluation of my implicit model. I've put some more thought into how to evaluate the combined probabilities I assign to the top 50 most populous countries and for this purpose I have made a model using Guesstimate [1] — the results of which is a mean of 7.5 (95% CI: 5.6, 9.4) countries exceeding 1M cases by the end of the year. However, I think this 95% CI is much too confident so instead of assuming a standard deviation of 1 I've used a normal distribution calculator [2] to assume a standard deviation of 2.5 so that ~55% instead of 95% of the probability distribution falls in the 5.6-9.4 range, which sounds much more plausible given the large amount of uncertainty we have. The values I've assigned to each bin assumes a normal distribution using these values. Also note that I've also changed some of the probabilities I've assigned to individual countries based on some more reading I've done about their current situations. And finally, big thanks to @jainsa for his commentary — I always welcome critical analysis that has the potential to help me make better forecasts! 97%	Russia
93%	South Africa
87%	Mexico
81%	Colombia
62%	Peru
61%	Bangladesh
31%	Argentina
3%	        China
1%	        Iran
0%           All other countries
75%         Wildcard -- some country not on the list above is likely to blow up between now and EOY.
Total = 6.9 additional countries. (I know I'm not doing the math right, but I'm not sure how to do it better. Suggestions welcome.)  I estimate that there is a >90% probability that the number ends up falling between 3 and 10 inclusive. I cannot see a rational argument for 15+ additional countries. The others just don't have a large enough population and/or have their COVID response too organized to be viable options. Big issues that affect my wildcard assumption: 
1) +0 vaccine: not really relevant I think. It's possible that one could exist in this timeframe, but is unlikely to be widely deployed in any of these countries by Oct/Nov. I don't think the possibility has a material impact on the estimates above
2) +50% mutation: I think there's a >25% probability of a significant new mutation that makes this more contagious.
3) +25% another (2nd? 3rd? 1st?) wave in the fall that pushes some of these countries in the norther hemisphere over 1M. => 2 of the countries above are southern hemisphere so maybe those will turn out to be lower probability. I'm assuming this is offset by increases with other countries in the northern hemisphere. There are more countries in the N than the S, especially large countries that could hit 1M, so it's a net positive.

This question depends on two factors. How the epidemic evolves and how many tests are done. The later should increase over time when test are being sent or produced at "frontline" countries.
There are 14 countries besides the USA and Brazil that already have more than 200k cases confirmed. With an average of 5-7k cases per day, they would have around 900-1260k new cases by the end of 2020.
Countries that don't have spread under control from the above group I have divided into three categories, based on the current and weekly new cases counts.
1. Certain (close to reaching 1m mark in month/two): Russia -  719k; India - 820k
2. Very possible (they have more than 5k new cases daily on top of 200k so far): Mexico - 289k (7k); South Africa 250k (12.3k)
3. Possible (they have less than 5k new cases daily but still a significant number of active cases - testing gap?): Peru - 319k (3.5k); Chile 309k (3k); Iran 252k (2.6k); Turkey 210 (1k); Pakistan - 246k (2.5-4k); Saudi Arabia 226k (3.1k)
4. Observation list (new cases partner are either with test flaws or are high but with a lower number of active cases): Bangladesh 178k (2.8k); Colombia - 133k (4-5k); Argentina 95k (3.1k); Indonesia 72k (2.7k); Bolivia 45k (1.5k)
There is also a group of countries that probably will have lot of cases, but don't do testing so we won't see that data: Ecuador, Bolivia, Nigeria, Kenia, Ghana, Iraq or other African, Middle East countries.  So we have 4 countries that possibly reach the 1m cases this year. From the other two groups, 6 out of 11.

I have been cracking the numbers more carefully and I am afraid that the number of countries with more than 1M cases is going to be large. My argument is based on the following: 1) the distribution of cases among the top-of-the-list countries will resemble the Zipf law (that is, the tenth country will have 1/10 the cases of the first), 2) the growth of worldwide cases is unlikely to acceletare. From 1) I can estimate that the top ten countries will have between 0.5-0.6 the total number of cases, with 0.2 for the top countrie. Since May the actual data have been 0.66-0.70 for the top ten and 0.26-0.31 for the top country in the list, with the numbers going doing (suggesting convergence). The distribution is not perfectly Zipf like, with the 10th country having between 1/11 and 1/12 the number of cases of the 1st country, yet this looks pretty good to me. Now if number of cases growth linearly, we will end up with about 40M cases at the end of the year, giving us about 7.9 countries with more than 1M cases (5.9 after removing US/Brazil). If we have a 1% growth per day (consistent below the growth we have had since May), we will end up with 100M cases and 19.9 countries expected to cross the 1M cases mark (17.9 after removing US/Brazil). If we allow for a 2% growth per day we will end with 330M cases, but I will not consider this scenario. The point is that anything from 5-17 (or even more) seems a pretty sensible expectation.

First approximation: a few obvious candidates for the 1M mark include Russia, India, Mexico, Bangladesh (plus other mentions in the comments), so we can remove the first bucket. Now as time goes by, the distribution of cases begins to resemble more and more a power-law distribution, concentrating about 2/3 of the total cases. Maybe by the end of the year this fraction could have fallen to 0.6 (maybe even less). If by then we have 15 / 27 / 38 / 50 million cases, we will end up with 9 / 16 / 22 / 30 million cases among the top 10 of the list. Now, if things converge to a power-law distribution with exponent 1 (i.e. 1/n, with n the order within the list), the first country in the list will have 1/3 of the previous estimate: 3 / 5 / 7 / 10 million cases, which means that the 1 million mark will be achieved by the 3rd, 5th, 7th and 10th country in the list (but probably a bit less, because actually the numbers probably decrease faster than 1/n). Removing two countries (US and Brazil), we are left with 1 / 3 / 5 / 8 countries, but I have assumed that there will be at least two, which the most probable outcome probably in the 4-6 countries bucket. Yet I will have to revise the projections for cases on 31st of December and the assumptions about the power-law distribution.

Very non-resilient (and I expect to change these a lot as I mull it over more carefully).  The bump at the high end is a fudge to account for 'correlated risk'. First is a large surge in incidence (e.g. a feared 'second wave', or (less likely) a shift internationally towards mitigation rather than suppression). The second is (I'd guess also unlikely) changes in case definition: e.g. including prevalence/presumptive estimates, or use of serology to confirm cases retrospectively. Currently anticipating no more than 3. Three factors: sufficient population to create the numbers, Ability to test large numbers of people effectively to confirm the numbers, and willingness of the government to report the numbers. Russia and China are almost certain to achieve this, but reporting is a different issue. Venezuela, India, and others likely will reach that many infections, but confirming them is harder.  Will watch and change as time passes, but at the moment, this is where I am at.

To assess the likelihood for this question, I have developed a framework based on 3 criteria:
1. Current number of cases (how far from 1M are we at the half-way point this year)
2. Strength of healthcare system
3. Country wealth (indicates testing access and ability to social distance/avoid interaction and earn a living) Most likely to cross 1M in my mind are Russia and India. Both have high case loads at the moment (>360k) and weaker healthcare systems. They also are both heavily dependent on the service sector which involves in-person interaction. Less likely, but still concerning our countries like Peru, Chile, and Mexico. All 3 are on very steep parts of the exponential curve and have limited healthcare access  That being said, they are at <250k cases and this have farther to go.  Other factors that could influence my outlook higher are:
1. A second wave of the virus in the fall. If it is very severe, that will obviously drive case counts up. I also don’t believe lockdown restrictions will be as intense so case counts should rise faster
2. The WHO shifts to some sort of estimation method based on longitudinal sampling of country populations  These two factors support increased risk on the upside. An interesting exercise would be to code the logistic regression I’ve been using for other questions to see what results I get.  More to come.
